article_text:
A voter casts her ballot at a polling station in Kahnmun, about 118 miles from Aizwal, the capital city of Mizoram on Apr. 11. Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

Mizoram went to polls on April 11, after the state government and the state’s electoral office asked the Election Commission of India to delay voting by two days.

Voters queued to enter a polling station in Kahnmun, some 190 kms from Aizwal, Mizoram, April 11. Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

The northeastern state was scheduled to go for polls on April 9 but was delayed due to security concerns.

Security personnel stood guard at a polling station in Kahnmun, Mizoram, April 11. Arindram Dey/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

Like most northeastern Indian states, Mizoram has been beset with insurgency.

An election official sat behind an electronic voting machine at a polling station in Aizwal, Mizoram, Apr. 11. Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

There are a total of 696, 448 voters in the state with 50.7% female voters and 49.3 male voters.

Follow India Real Time on Twitter @WSJIndia.
